column4: Yeah, actually.... is there any sort of gui fstab-editor in ubuntu?  I haven't found one.... gparted displays mountpoints, but doesn't let you change 'em
again, I'm talking gutsy
fstab is one of those things where if you do not understand the file by looking at it in a text editor then you should probably not change it
not true.  Some of the basic things in the fstab are things which most people can understand, but they daren't edit the file manually because of the things they *don't* understand
maybe but i dont want to get the blame for telling someone to edit a file and then their ubuntu is broke.
anyway, I don't want a gui fstab editor because I need one, I want one because I'm annoyed that I have to fire up vi for something so simple and basic
nano! :)
that's the point---let a simple gui frontend do it safely, rather than getting inexperienced users to do it by hand
ubuntu is setup in such a way that fstab should never need to be edited
false.  It got it wrong with a few of my non-ubuntu partitions.
after an upgrade, which it should be able to handle.
i didnt say ubuntu would setup fstab correctly, it *should* set it up correctly and if it doesnt then a bug report would do swell :)
anyway, the installer expects the user to know what a mountpoint is, so why hide them from that point on?
all I'm saying is it seems inconsistent

its not inconsistent with ubuntu's goals. The goal of ubuntu is to make the linux environment seemingly painless for the average desktop user. the average desktop user does not want to mess with a file like fstab and doesnt want to take the time to learn it

I'm not saying make something which is a direct analog of the fstab as a gui app---I'm just saying, give the user *some* way to change where filesystems are mounted, and to allow newly-found filesystems to be mounted without root.
i think newly mounted filesystems are mounted without root?

users can already edit partitions with gparted, and gparted *tells* them where they're going to be mounted.... wouldn't be too hard to add the ability to change that, given that you can change all the other partition properties listed in gparted
yeah, on external drives.
the only problem i see with editing fstab (user aside) is that ubuntu expects certain partitions to be mounted in a particular spot and in a particular way.
yeah.  So, make those uneditable through the gui
i dunno i just provided my 2 cents. you could post something in the idea pool section of the ubuntuforums and probably get some better responses
okie dokie.  Sorry---I like to argue way too much :-\
didn't meant to shout at you
